equality guaranteed by the Civil
Rights Act means and to know
that they would have to work
hard to compensate for the years
Of deprivation. eve must pro-
vide the training that Negro youth
need. rather lamenting that they
do not have it."


She continued, "Women have a
special responsibility to make
certain that the new equal OPP
portunities are utilized" Gas
a group. Negro women can work
with other women's groups and
public officials to help insure
equal opportunities"

James C. "Jim'' Brown, SIS, is
a candidate for State Senator -,
Maricopa County.


He has served as president of
the Arizona Democratic Associa-
ton; vice-president of the Sunny
slope Democratic Club; member
of the Southside Democratic Club:
Chairman of District 81: Vice
chairman of District 80; Precinct
Captain of Cactus Precinct and
Wickenburg |, and, since 1860,
has been state delegate to the
Arizona State Democratic Con-
vention.


He is the business manager
for Arizona Trailer Convoy.

Jim Brown Seeks
State Senate Post

WASHINGTON, DC. To OBJ
serve the 89th birthday of
Mary Mcleod Bethune, founder
of the National Council of
Negro Women, inc. and
Bethune-Co okman College, a
"Bethune Birthday Weekend"
was held at Bethune-Cookman
College in Daytona Beach.
Florida. July 10 IL.


Miss Dorothy l. Height.
National President, National
Council of Negro Women was
keynote speaker. Using the con-
ference theme "Women in the
Quest for Equality" she urged

NEW YORK NAACP has asked
90 National chain businesses to
direct their outlets Gin areas
where segregation has pre-
vailed to comply i'm
mediately' with the provisions
of the new Civil Rights Act of
1864.


In a letter NAACP Executive
Secretary Roy Wilkins asked
them to notify al their southern
outlets of the claw requirement
NAACP AIerts Firms To Heed Civil Rights Law

for equal service to all
customers"


BY July IL, replies indicating
compliance had been received
from three oil companies Sun,
Texaco and Standard Oil; two
theatre chains = Trans-Lux Cor
poration and American Broad
casting Paramount Theatres,
Inc; and two variety store chains
F. W. Woolworth and w. T.
Grant.

Jacquene the eight year old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Esaw
Long, Ave.. celebrated birthday with family
friends Saturday evening, July l8.


Shown above Jacqeine. honoree, with tiara
Gregory. Anthony, Michael and Cynthia Long.


Also pictured Debbe Elaine and Daphne Easter; Frankie
and Stee Banks; Debe Carolyn and Clovis Campbe Shirley
and usyn Bum Debe and Sandra Matthews; Darlene Hans
andD

party honoring Phoenix
day the home of Mrs. Jessie Jackson W.
Mrs. Beatrice Cofy, Mrs. Jacksons Waco
Texas and her niece Miss Paulette Roverson, Marlin
Guests included Mesdmes Maggie Scott Forene eres Mona
Watson, Bonnie Davis Lula Clark, and Audrie Relf


Also attending Beverly and Larry Dunbar Mrs. Tiny
Pine Dunbar Dana Dnforth John MITCHELL Cornell Johnson
and Clifford Johnson.
